questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman at 10 weeks gestation presents to the antenatal clinic for her routine prenatal visit. She reports a recent rash that started three days ago, starting from her face and spreading to her trunk and limbs. She mentions that she has never been vaccinated against rubella and has no history of prior infection. On examination, her temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), and she has a generalized maculopapular rash. Laboratory tests reveal a positive rubella IgM antibody. What is the most appropriate management option for this patient?

options.label: D
options.text: "Counseling regarding the potential risks in continuation of pregnancy"

questions.correct_answer: D. "Counseling regarding the potential risks in continuation of pregnancy"
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) "Counseling regarding the potential risks in continuation of pregnancy"

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Rubella infection in the first trimester is associated with a high risk of congenital rubella syndrome, which includes congenital cataracts, congenital heart defects, and sensorineural hearing loss.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with persistent vaginal bleeding and a history of molar pregnancy that was evacuated three months ago. Pathology report confirmed a diagnosis of choriocarcinoma. The patient undergoes staging workup, including imaging and laboratory tests. Which of the following prognostic scoring systems is commonly used to assess the risk and prognosis in choriocarcinoma?

options.label: A
options.text: International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics (FIGO) scoring system

questions.correct_answer: A. International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics (FIGO) scoring system
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics (FIGO) scoring system

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The FIGO prognostic scoring system is essential for determining the risk category of gestational trophoblastic neoplasia, guiding treatment decisions with single-agent or multi-agent chemotherapy based on the patient’s risk score.
  • ➤ FIGO prognostic scoring system

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman at 10 weeks gestation presents to the emergency department with vaginal bleeding and lower abdominal cramping for the past 48 hours. On examination, the cervix is dilated, and products of conception are visualized in the cervical os. Transvaginal ultrasound reveals an empty gestational sac in the uterine cavity. The patient's vital signs are stable. Which of the following is the most appropriate management option for this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: Administration of misoprostol for medical management

options.label: D
options.text: Initiation of antibiotic therapy and observation

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Immediate surgical evacuation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of inevitable abortion with an open cervix and visible products of conception, the most appropriate management is surgical evacuation to prevent complications such as hemorrhage or infection. Misoprostol is typically reserved for cases where the os is closed, such as in missed abortions.
  • ➤ inevitable abortion
  • ➤ surgical evacuation

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman at 26 weeks gestation presents to the antenatal clinic with a history of Rh-negative blood type. She had two previous pregnancies, both resulting in Rh-positive infants. Her current pregnancy is also Rh-positive. Maternal antibody screening reveals the presence of anti-D antibodies. What is the most appropriate management option for this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Early delivery of the fetus via induction of labor

options.label: C
options.text: Initiation of serial fetal Doppler ultrasound monitoring

options.label: D
options.text: Administration of anti-D immune globulin (Rh-immune globulin)

questions.correct_answer: C. Initiation of serial fetal Doppler ultrasound monitoring
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Initiation of serial fetal Doppler ultrasound monitoring

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of Rh isoimmunization , monitor for fetal anemia using MCA-PSV Doppler ultrasound once the antibody titer exceeds the critical threshold (usually ≥1:16). Anti-D immune globulin is only used prophylactically and is ineffective once the mother has become isoimmunized.
  • ➤ Rh isoimmunization
  • ➤ fetal anemia
  • ➤ MCA-PSV Doppler ultrasound

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman at 40 weeks gestation is in active labor and is being monitored with continuous electronic fetal heart rate monitoring (CTG). The CTG tracing shows recurrent variable decelerations, and the obstetric team suspects fetal acidemia. The decision is made to perform a fetal scalp blood sampling (FBS). Which of the following is the most appropriate interpretation of a fetal scalp pH of 7.25 obtained during FBS?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Normal fetal acid-base status

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fetal scalp blood sampling (FBS) provides a direct assessment of the fetal acid-base status during labor. A pH of ≥ 7.25 is normal, while a pH ≤ 7.19 indicates significant fetal hypoxia requiring immediate intervention.
  • ➤ pH of ≥ 7.25
  • ➤ pH ≤ 7.19

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman presents for Down syndrome screening. She is currently at 13 weeks gestation. Maternal serum screening is performed, and the results show an elevated free beta-human chorionic gonadotropin (β-hCG) level and a reduced pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A) level of 0.8 MoM. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Proceed with diagnostic testing, such as chorionic villus sampling (CVS)

options.label: B
options.text: Repeat the maternal serum screening in the second trimester

options.label: C
options.text: Perform an ultrasound for nuchal translucency measurement

questions.correct_answer: C. Perform an ultrasound for nuchal translucency measurement
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Perform an ultrasound for nuchal translucency measurement

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the first trimester (11–14 weeks), the best approach for Down syndrome screening is the combined test , which includes maternal serum markers (β-hCG and PAPP-A) and nuchal translucency (NT) measurement . If the risk is high, diagnostic testing such as CVS or amniocentesis should be performed to confirm the diagnosis.
  • ➤ first trimester
  • ➤ combined test
  • ➤ maternal serum markers
  • ➤ nuchal translucency (NT) measurement
  • ➤ CVS
  • ➤ amniocentesis

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman, G4P3 presents at 34 weeks gestation for an antenatal visit. She has a history of previous cesarean deliveries. During her routine ultrasound examination, the radiologist reports findings suggestive of placenta accreta. The patient has no symptoms at present. Which of the following is the most appropriate management option for this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Expectant management with close monitoring and regular ultrasounds

options.label: D
options.text: Initiation of antenatal corticosteroids and scheduled cesarean section at 37 weeks gestation

questions.correct_answer: C. Preoperative planning for cesarean hysterectomy
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Preoperative planning for cesarean hysterectomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of placenta accreta , the management involves planned cesarean hysterectomy between 34–37 weeks gestation in a well-equipped setting to prevent life-threatening hemorrhage. The placenta should not be manually removed during delivery, as this can lead to massive bleeding.
  • ➤ placenta accreta
  • ➤ planned cesarean hysterectomy
  • ➤ 34–37 weeks
  • ➤ not be manually removed

questions.text: A 25-year-old pregnant woman at 28 weeks gestation presents to the antenatal clinic for a routine check-up. She is enrolled in the Anemia Mukt Bharat campaign, a national initiative in India aimed at reducing the prevalence of anemia in pregnant women. The patient's hemoglobin level was measured at 9.2 g/dL at 24 weeks. Despite receiving iron supplementation twice, a day, for the past month, her hemoglobin level has not significantly improved. Which of the following is the most appropriate management option for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Increase the dosage of oral iron supplementation

options.label: C
options.text: Perform further investigations to identify underlying causes of anemia

options.label: D
options.text: Refer the patient for blood transfusion

questions.correct_answer: C. Perform further investigations to identify underlying causes of anemia
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Perform further investigations to identify underlying causes of anemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Anemia Mukt Bharat campaign focuses on addressing both nutritional and non-nutritional causes of anemia. If a pregnant woman’s hemoglobin level does not improve after 3 weeks of iron supplementation, further investigations must be performed to rule out conditions like infections, hemoglobinopathies, or vitamin deficiencies.
  • ➤ Anemia Mukt Bharat
  • ➤ 3 weeks
  • ➤ further investigations

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents to her obstetrician for her first prenatal visit at 8 weeks gestation. She has a history of epilepsy and has been taking an antiepileptic medication, Drug Y, for the past two years. Drug Y is known to have teratogenic effects and is associated with an increased risk of major congenital malformations. The woman is concerned about the potential risks to her developing fetus. Which of the following is the most appropriate management option for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Discontinue the use of Drug Y immediately

options.label: B
options.text: Continue using Drug Y but at a lower dosage

options.label: C
options.text: Switch to an alternative antiepileptic medication with lower teratogenic risk

options.label: D
options.text: Perform detailed fetal ultrasound examination and genetic testing to assess for any abnormalities

questions.correct_answer: D. Perform detailed fetal ultrasound examination and genetic testing to assess for any abnormalities
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Perform detailed fetal ultrasound examination and genetic testing to assess for any abnormalities

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In pregnant women with epilepsy, it is crucial to switch to antiepileptic medications with a lower teratogenic risk such as lamotrigine or levetiracetam , ideally as monotherapy. Abrupt discontinuation of AEDs should be avoided to prevent maternal seizures, and detailed fetal anomaly scans are part of follow-up but not the initial management priority at 8 weeks.
  • ➤ switch to antiepileptic medications with a lower teratogenic risk
  • ➤ lamotrigine or levetiracetam

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman complains of acute-onset severe abdominal pain. 48 hours after an uncomplicated repeat cesarean section delivery. Physical examination reveals tachycardia, and hypotension. There is diffuse abdominal tenderness and rebound tenderness. Laboratory tests show leukocytosis and metabolic acidosis. Imaging reveals free fluid in the abdominal cavity. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Bowel perforation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bowel perforation after cesarean section is a rare but serious complication that can occur due to trauma, infection, or ischemia. Clinical signs such as peritonitis, leukocytosis, metabolic acidosis, and free fluid are key to distinguishing it from obstetric emergencies such as uterine rupture or hemorrhagic shock.
  • ➤ rare but serious
  • ➤ peritonitis, leukocytosis, metabolic acidosis, and free fluid

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman undergoes a routine ultrasound examination at 22 weeks gestation. The ultrasound reveals fetal ascites, pleural effusion, and skin edema. The umbilical vein Doppler shows increased Pulsatility. Fetal echocardiogram demonstrates cardiomegaly and signs of congestive heart failure. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this fetus?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hydrops fetalis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hydrops fetalis refers to the abnormal accumulation of fluid in two or more fetal compartments and can be either immune or non-immune in origin. Key causes include Rh isoimmunization (immune hydrops) and congenital infections, chromosomal anomalies, or fetal heart failure (non-immune hydrops).
  • ➤ two or more fetal compartments
  • ➤ immune
  • ➤ non-immune
  • ➤ Rh isoimmunization
  • ➤ congenital infections, chromosomal anomalies, or fetal heart failure

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, P2L2 presents to her obstetrician for a postnatal check-up two weeks after delivering her second child. She reports feeling persistently sad, fatigued, and overwhelmed since giving birth. She has difficulty sleeping and has lost interest in activities she once enjoyed. Her appetite has decreased, and she feels guilty about not being able to bond with her baby. The woman's husband also notes that she has been tearful and emotionally withdrawn. On further evaluation, she meets the criteria for a diagnosis of postpartum depression. What is the most appropriate management option for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Encourage her to engage in regular exercise and practice stress-reduction techniques

options.label: B
options.text: Provide reassurance that these feelings are normal and expected after childbirth

options.label: C
options.text: Admit her and start SSRIs with close monitoring

options.label: D
options.text: Recommend psychotherapy, such as cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT)

questions.correct_answer: D. Recommend psychotherapy, such as cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Recommend psychotherapy, such as cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Postpartum depression should be differentiated from postpartum blues , which is self-limiting, and postpartum psychosis , which requires immediate hospitalization. Treatment for postpartum depression includes psychotherapy (e.g., CBT) for mild to moderate cases and SSRIs for moderate to severe cases,
  • ➤ Postpartum depression
  • ➤ postpartum blues
  • ➤ postpartum psychosis
  • ➤ psychotherapy (e.g., CBT)
  • ➤ SSRIs

questions.text: Anemia Mukt Bharat (AMB) is a national initiative in India aimed at reducing the prevalence of anemia in specific vulnerable populations, including pregnant women. Which of the following statements about Anemia Mukt Bharat in pregnancy is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Anemia Mukt Bharat focuses on urban areas of India

options.label: B
options.text: The initiative primarily targets women in their third trimester of pregnancy

options.label: C
options.text: Anemia Mukt Bharat aims to provide free prenatal vitamins to pregnant women

options.label: D
options.text: Anemia Mukt Bharat emphasizes iron and folic acid supplementation during pregnancy and also in reproductive age women.

questions.correct_answer: D. Anemia Mukt Bharat emphasizes iron and folic acid supplementation during pregnancy and also in reproductive age women.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Anemia Mukt Bharat emphasizes iron and folic acid supplementation during pregnancy and also in reproductive age women.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Anemia Mukt Bharat (AMB) campaign aims to improve maternal and child health by addressing anemia in pregnant women, reproductive age women, and children through iron and folic acid supplementation, deworming, and dietary interventions . The campaign is designed to be inclusive, covering both rural and urban populations.
  • ➤ Anemia Mukt Bharat (AMB)
  • ➤ pregnant women, reproductive age women, and children
  • ➤ iron and folic acid supplementation, deworming, and dietary interventions

questions.text: A 30-year-old Primi, presents at 35 weeks gestation with severe nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. She also reports a generalized feeling of malaise and fatigue. On physical examination, her blood pressure is elevated (160/100 mmHg), and she appears jaundiced. Laboratory tests reveal elevated liver enzymes and hyperbilirubinemia. She is also hypoglycemic. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this pregnant patient?
questions.correct_answer: B. Acute fatty liver of pregnancy (AFLP)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Acute fatty liver of pregnancy (AFLP)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acute fatty liver of pregnancy (AFLP) typically occurs in the third trimester and presents with systemic symptoms, liver dysfunction, hypoglycemia, and coagulopathy .
  • ➤ Acute fatty liver of pregnancy (AFLP)
  • ➤ third trimester
  • ➤ systemic symptoms, liver dysfunction, hypoglycemia, and coagulopathy

questions.text: A 35-year-old G2P1 at 37 weeks gestation presents to the obstetrician's office for a routine check-up. On examination, it is confirmed that the baby is in a breech presentation with the buttocks closest to the birth canal. The woman is keen on attempting a vaginal delivery and expresses concerns about the breech presentation. After counseling and discussing the available options, the obstetrician decides to offer an external cephalic version (ECV) to the patient. Which of the following is the most appropriate consideration before proceeding with the ECV?

options.label: A
options.text: Fetal heart rate assessment during the procedure

options.label: B
options.text: Maternal pelvic examination for Bishop score

options.label: C
options.text: Administering intravenous pain relief medication to the patient

options.label: D
options.text: Checking the patient's blood pressure for hypertension

questions.correct_answer: A. Fetal heart rate assessment during the procedure
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Fetal heart rate assessment during the procedure

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Before performing external cephalic version (ECV) , it is crucial to assess the fetal heart rate and ensure that there is no fetal distress . Monitoring the FHR during and after the procedure helps detect complications early. The Bishop score, pain management, and maternal blood pressure monitoring are secondary considerations compared to fetal well-being.
  • ➤ external cephalic version (ECV)
  • ➤ fetal heart rate
  • ➤ no fetal distress

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman, G2P1 presents at 18 weeks gestation with a history of a previous preterm birth at 28 weeks. She is concerned about the risk of another preterm delivery in the current pregnancy. On examination, her cervix is found to be dilated to 2 cm and effaced. She has no contractions at the time of evaluation. Fetal ultrasound shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient to reduce the risk of preterm birth?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Cerclage placement

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with a history of preterm birth and cervical dilation without contractions in the current pregnancy, emergency cerclage is the most appropriate intervention. Progesterone is used in patients with short cervix without dilation , and tocolytics are reserved for cases with active contractions .
  • ➤ cervical dilation without contractions
  • ➤ emergency cerclage
  • ➤ short cervix without dilation
  • ➤ active contractions

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman at 30 weeks gestation is referred to a high-risk obstetrician for suspected fetal growth restriction (FGR). The patient has a history of poorly controlled type 1 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. On examination, her fundal height is consistently measuring below the expected range for gestational age. Fetal ultrasound shows estimated fetal weight below the 5th percentile, and Doppler ultrasound demonstrates absent end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery. The amniotic fluid index is within normal limits. The patient's blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg, and she has trace proteinuria. What is the Next best management approach for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Corticosteroids to enhance fetal lung maturity

options.label: B
options.text: Begin antihypertensive therapy to control blood pressure

options.label: C
options.text: Perform immediate cesarean section for preterm delivery

options.label: D
options.text: Admit the patient for close maternal and fetal monitoring

questions.correct_answer: A. Corticosteroids to enhance fetal lung maturity
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Corticosteroids to enhance fetal lung maturity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of fetal growth restriction (FGR) with absent end-diastolic flow before 34 weeks gestation, the management includes corticosteroid administration to enhance fetal lung maturity , followed by planning for delivery.
  • ➤ fetal growth restriction (FGR)
  • ➤ absent end-diastolic flow
  • ➤ corticosteroid administration to enhance fetal lung maturity

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the obstetric clinic for her first prenatal visit at 9 weeks gestation. This is her first pregnancy, and she has no significant medical history. During the ultrasound examination, the presence of three gestational sacs with fetal poles and heartbeats is noted. The examination also reveals a monochorionic triamniotic triplet pregnancy. The patient is informed about the complexity and increased risks associated with a triplet pregnancy. What is the most critical complication unique to monochorionic triamniotic triplet pregnancies that requires close monitoring?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The unique complication of monochorionic pregnancies (both twins and triplets) is twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS) due to vascular anastomoses within the shared placenta. Cord entanglement becomes a unique concern in monoamniotic pregnancies .
  • ➤ unique
  • ➤ monochorionic pregnancies
  • ➤ twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS)
  • ➤ Cord entanglement
  • ➤ monoamniotic pregnancies

questions.text: Implantation occurs approximately how soon after fertilization?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)  6 days

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Implantation begins around 6–7 days after fertilization and is completed by day 10 . This process is critical for establishing a successful pregnancy.
  • ➤ Implantation
  • ➤ 6–7 days
  • ➤ day 10

questions.text: A 24y primigravida gets an anomaly scan at 20 weeks. This is the 3D image of the face. What drug would she have been taking?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Sodium valproate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sodium valproate is highly teratogenic and is strongly associated with cleft lip, cardiovascular defects, and neural tube defects . Careful selection of antiepileptic medications is essential during pregnancy, with lamotrigine and levetiracetam considered safer alternatives.
  • ➤ Sodium valproate
  • ➤ cleft lip, cardiovascular defects, and neural tube defects
  • ➤ lamotrigine
  • ➤ levetiracetam

questions.text: A 28-year-old doctor working for Medicine sans frontiers is travelling to several countries of Africa. She is 12 weeks pregnant and visits for yellow fever vaccination which is mandatory for travel to some countries in Africa. As it’s a live vaccine, she is worried if it is safe for her. What will you advise?

options.label: C
options.text: Take the vaccine but avoid travel

questions.correct_answer: D. Take the vaccine and travel
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Take the vaccine and travel

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases where travel to yellow fever endemic areas is essential, the yellow fever vaccine can be safely administered during pregnancy as the benefits far outweigh the theoretical risks.
  • ➤ yellow fever endemic areas
  • ➤ yellow fever vaccine

questions.text: The only vaccine known to cause fetal harm is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Smallpox

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The smallpox vaccine is contraindicated in pregnancy due to its proven teratogenic effects . In contrast, other live vaccines such as MMR and varicella have only a theoretical risk of fetal harm, and inactivated vaccines like rabies and COVID-19 vaccines are safe during pregnancy.
  • ➤ smallpox vaccine
  • ➤ proven teratogenic effects
  • ➤ theoretical risk
  • ➤ safe

questions.text: A 23-year-old primigravida presents at 8 weeks pregnant. She is troubled by constant nausea and vomiting which occurs 2-3 times a day but she is able to keep her food down and is tolerating oral fluids. Which is the drug of choice for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Pyridoxine + Doxylamine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The first-line drug of choice for managing nausea and vomiting of pregnancy (NVP) is pyridoxine (vitamin B6) + doxylamine . Non-pharmacological options such as ginger extract can be used as supportive measures, while second-line drugs like promethazine and ondansetron are reserved for more severe or refractory cases.
  • ➤ first-line drug of choice
  • ➤ nausea and vomiting of pregnancy (NVP)
  • ➤ pyridoxine (vitamin B6) + doxylamine
  • ➤ ginger extract
  • ➤ promethazine
  • ➤ ondansetron

questions.text: A couple visits the antenatal OPD. She is G2 and currently 10 weeks. Her previous child was diagnosed with cystic fibrosis in childhood. She is very concerned about the risk of cystic fibrosis in the current pregnancy. What is the next best step?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Chorionic villous sampling

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In pregnancies at high risk for a known genetic disorder like cystic fibrosis, early diagnostic testing using CVS at 10–13 weeks is the preferred approach. This provides confirmation of the fetal genetic status early in the pregnancy, allowing for informed decision-making.
  • ➤ known genetic disorder
  • ➤ CVS at 10–13 weeks

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida presents for her regular antenatal checkup at 32 weeks. On examination, the fundal grip reveals a hard ballotable structure. What is your inference?

options.label: A
options.text: The fetus is in cephalic presentation

options.label: B
options.text: The fetus is in breech presentation

options.label: C
options.text: The fetus is in transverse lie

options.label: D
options.text: The presentation cannot be made out

questions.correct_answer: B. The fetus is in breech presentation
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) The fetus is in breech presentation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A hard, ballotable structure in the fundus typically indicates the fetal head , suggesting a breech presentation . Leopold maneuvers are an essential part of late pregnancy assessment to determine fetal lie, presentation, and position.
  • ➤ hard, ballotable structure
  • ➤ fundus
  • ➤ fetal head
  • ➤ breech presentation

questions.text: Inadequate uterine contractions are defined as uterine contractions
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) < 180 Montevideo units

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Uterine contractions are considered inadequate if they generate < 180 MVUs over 10 minutes. Augmentation with oxytocin or other interventions is indicated to strengthen contractions when the MVUs are suboptimal.
  • ➤ inadequate if they generate < 180 MVUs

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents to the prenatal OPD. This is her 4 th pregnancy. She had a preterm twin delivery last year at 32 weeks out of which only 1 baby survived. She also gives a history of 2 spontaneous abortions prior to the twin pregnancy. What is her parity index?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) G4P1A2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In twin deliveries, the number of fetuses does not affect the parity count —it is counted as one delivery event . Abortions are only counted if they occur before 20 weeks gestation .
  • ➤ fetuses
  • ➤ parity count
  • ➤ one delivery event
  • ➤ before 20 weeks gestation

questions.text: A 29-year-old with no prenatal care presents for her screening ultrasound at 28 weeks gestation. Evaluation of the fetal head reveals this abnormality. What percentage of fetuses with this condition are born to women at low risk for this anomaly?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 90%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anencephaly is a preventable neural tube defect in many cases through adequate folic acid supplementation . However, 90% of cases occur in low-risk women who have no identifiable predisposing factors, emphasizing the importance of routine folic acid intake before and during early pregnancy.
  • ➤ Anencephaly
  • ➤ adequate folic acid supplementation
  • ➤ 90%
  • ➤ low-risk women

questions.text: Following delivery of a twin pregnancy which was unbooked, the placenta is examined and is as shown. What is the likely time of splitting of the embryo?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) After the 8thday

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In monozygotic twinning , the timing of embryo splitting determines whether twins will be dichorionic diamniotic (DCDA), monochorionic diamniotic (MCDA), monochorionic monoamniotic (MCMA), or conjoined twins . In MCMA pregnancies, the embryo splits after the 8th day , resulting in one placenta and one amniotic sac .
  • ➤ monozygotic twinning
  • ➤ dichorionic diamniotic (DCDA), monochorionic diamniotic (MCDA), monochorionic monoamniotic (MCMA),
  • ➤ conjoined twins
  • ➤ 8th day
  • ➤ one placenta
  • ➤ one amniotic sac

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman comes to the office with a 3-day history of intermittent lower abdominal pain and vaginal spotting. The pain was initially mild but has gotten worse. Her last menstrual period was 6 weeks ago. She takes no medication and has no allergies. The patient is in college. She is afebrile, BP is 110/70mmHg and pulse is 80/min. On bimanual examination there is right adnexal tenderness and the os is closed with a normal sized uterus. A UPT is positive, and a trans-abdominal scan does not show an intra-uterine gestation. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Trans vaginal scan

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A transvaginal ultrasound (TVS) is the preferred initial diagnostic step for evaluating early pregnancy complications, such as suspected ectopic pregnancy, in stable patients with a positive UPT and no intrauterine gestation on a trans-abdominal scan.
  • ➤ transvaginal ultrasound (TVS)

questions.text: Which of the following statements about fetal physiology is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: The fetal lungs are the primary organs responsible for oxygen exchange

options.label: B
options.text: The fetal ductus arteriosus allows oxygenated blood to bypass the lungs and flow directly to the systemic circulation.

options.label: C
options.text: Fetal hemoglobin has a lower affinity for oxygen compared to adult hemoglobin.

options.label: D
options.text: The fetal liver is fully responsible for the metabolism and detoxification of drugs and waste products.

questions.correct_answer: B. The fetal ductus arteriosus allows oxygenated blood to bypass the lungs and flow directly to the systemic circulation.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) The fetal ductus arteriosus allows oxygenated blood to bypass the lungs and flow directly to the systemic circulation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The ductus arteriosus is a fetal circulatory shunt that allows oxygenated blood to bypass the lungs and flow into systemic circulation. This is a key feature of fetal circulation due to the non-functionality of fetal lungs in utero.
  • ➤ ductus arteriosus

questions.text: A 24-year-old primi is in labor. The baseline FHR is 110bpm. All are possible causes for fetal bradycardia except?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Maternal fever

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fetal bradycardia can be caused by maternal beta blocker use, hypothermia, fetal hypoxia, and hypoglycemia . However, maternal fever is associated with fetal tachycardia rather than bradycardia.
  • ➤ maternal beta blocker use, hypothermia, fetal hypoxia, and hypoglycemia
  • ➤ maternal fever
  • ➤ tachycardia

questions.text: A 26-year-old patient who is 4 weeks postpartum presents with a 1-day history of fever of 100.9 and breast tenderness. She has been breast feeding without problems and reports no other symptoms. Her left breast has a 4cm area of induration and erythema at the 3 o’clock position that is tender to palpation. Milk expressed from that breast is white. Which is incorrect regarding this?

options.label: A
options.text: The most common organisms are Staph aureus

options.label: C
options.text: Dicloxacillin is the antibiotic of choice

options.label: D
options.text: The infection commonly is transmitted through the infants nasopharynx

questions.correct_answer: B. Breast feeding should be discontinued
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Breast feeding should be discontinued

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of lactational mastitis , breastfeeding should be continued to ensure proper drainage of the affected breast. The main causative organism is Staphylococcus aureus , and the first-line treatment is dicloxacillin. Avoiding early cessation of breastfeeding can help prevent complications like abscess formation.
  • ➤ lactational mastitis

questions.text: A 27-year-old patient at 37 weeks gestation presents with a 2-day history of fever of 101 0 F, loss of fluid from the vagina and diffuse abdominal tenderness. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Chorioamnionitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chorioamnionitis is a common complication of prolonged rupture of membranes (PROM) and is characterized by maternal fever, uterine tenderness, and fetal tachycardia .
  • ➤ Chorioamnionitis
  • ➤ prolonged rupture of membranes (PROM)
  • ➤ maternal fever, uterine tenderness, and fetal tachycardia

questions.text: Which of the following medical therapies has been associated with a modest decrease in the incidence of pre-eclampsia in women at increased risk?

options.label: C
options.text: Both aspirin and Low molecular weight heparin

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Aspirin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Low-dose aspirin (75–150 mg) initiated before 16 weeks of gestation is an effective, evidence-based intervention to reduce the incidence of pre-eclampsia in high-risk women. In contrast, low molecular weight heparin is indicated primarily for the prevention of thrombotic complications in conditions like APLA syndrome rather than for pre-eclampsia prevention.
  • ➤ Low-dose aspirin (75–150 mg)
  • ➤ before 16 weeks of gestation
  • ➤ low molecular weight heparin
  • ➤ APLA syndrome

questions.text: A 34-year-old P3 begins having heavy bleeding following a vaginal delivery. You giver her carboprost tromethaprine and perform the maneuver the pictured below and shifted to the OT. What is the name of this maneuver?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Bimanual uterine compression

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bimanual uterine compression is an essential mechanical intervention for the management of atonic PPH . It helps control bleeding until definitive medical or surgical management is implemented.
  • ➤ Bimanual uterine compression
  • ➤ atonic PPH

questions.text: A 24-year-old P1L1 Undergoes an obstetric hysterectomy for severe post partum haemorrhage. She has received 5 units packed cells in view of severe blood loss. However, despite hysterectomy, bleeding continues from the vault. What is the likely etiology of bleeding?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Dilutional coagulopathy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dilutional coagulopathy or DIC is a significant cause of persistent bleeding following obstetric hemorrhage and massive transfusion. It results from depletion of coagulation factors and platelets. Prompt correction with FFP, cryoprecipitate, and platelets is crucial to restore hemostasis.
  • ➤ Dilutional coagulopathy or DIC
  • ➤ FFP, cryoprecipitate, and platelets

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman has PPH. Surgical devascularization is being done as shown. Which vessel is being ligated in the image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Utero-ovarian

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Utero-ovarian artery ligation is a surgical technique to control blood flow to the uterus in cases of refractory PPH . This step helps reduce the risk of massive hemorrhage while preserving ovarian function.
  • ➤ Utero-ovarian artery ligation
  • ➤ refractory PPH

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman presents with decreased interest in sexual intercourse for 6 months. She also complains of recent onset painful intercourse, and this has further decreased her interest. She had a laparoscopic hysterectomy at 40y for adenomyosis. The ovaries were conserved. On examination, her vitals are normal. The vulva has scant pubic hair and the vulvo-vaginal mucosa is pale. The uterus is absent and there is no significant finding on bimanual exam. Which investigation will help diagnose her condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Serum FSH

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In women with a history of hysterectomy who present with symptoms of hypoestrogenism such as vaginal dryness, dyspareunia, and reduced libido, serum FSH levels can confirm the diagnosis of menopause. Elevated FSH levels (typically >40 IU/L) are consistent with ovarian failure and menopause.
  • ➤ symptoms of hypoestrogenism
  • ➤ FSH levels

questions.text: A 30-year-old old primigravida at 7 weeks presents to the emergency with vaginal bleeding. She gives a history of dark brown vaginal bleeding and mild abdominal cramping. She also has been complaining of nausea and vomiting which has worsened over the last week. The abdomen is soft and a speculum exam reveals a closed os. A pelvic ultrasound is as shown.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Twin Pregnancy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The lambda sign or “twin peak sign” on ultrasound is a reliable indicator of dichorionic diamniotic (DCDA) twin pregnancy , where each twin has a separate chorion and amnion. Twin pregnancies are at a higher risk for complications such as threatened abortion, preterm labor, and hyperemesis gravidarum due to increased β-hCG levels.
  • ➤ lambda sign
  • ➤ dichorionic diamniotic (DCDA) twin pregnancy

questions.text: A woman undergoes a radical hysterectomy with bilateral pelvic and para-aortic lymph node dissection for a 2-cm squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix". On final pathologic evaluation of the surgical specimen, the parametria are positive for cancer involvement. Based on these findings, which International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics (FIGO) clinical stage is she assigned?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) IB2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cervical cancer staging is determined clinically, with imaging modalities such as MRI or CT aiding the process. The findings of parametrium involvement on histopathology do not alter the clinical staging, which remains 1B2 for a 2 cm lesion confined to the cervix.
  • ➤ 1B2

questions.text: The image shown is of a colposcopy. Identify the yellow line
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Original Squamo-columnar junction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The original squamo-columnar junction represents the initial meeting point of squamous and columnar epithelium before physiological changes occur.
  • ➤ original squamo-columnar junction

questions.text: More than 100 human papillomavirus (HPV) types have been identified to date. Clinically, HPV types are classified as high risk (HR) or low risk based upon their oncogenic potential. Which two HR HPV types together account for approximately 70 percent of cervical cancers worldwide?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 16 and 18

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ HPV 16 and 18 are responsible for the majority of cervical cancers. Vaccines targeting these high-risk types (e.g., the bivalent, quadrivalent, and nonavalent HPV vaccines) significantly reduce the incidence of cervical cancer and high-grade cervical lesions.
  • ➤ 16 and 18

questions.text: As shown in this image of vaginal prolapse, when the leading edge of bulge is within 1 cm distal to the hymen, a patient is said to have which stage of prolapse?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Stage II

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The POP-Q system is the most standardized and objective method for describing pelvic organ prolapse. In clinical practice, the hymen serves as the primary reference point for determining the stage of prolapse.
  • ➤ POP-Q system
  • ➤ hymen

questions.text: Estrogen replacement therapy is contraindicated in women with all EXCEPT which of the following?

options.label: D
options.text: Abnormal genital bleeding of unknown etiology

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Vasomotor symptoms

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The primary indication for HRT is the management of vasomotor symptoms in menopausal women. HRT should not be used in cases of active liver disease, breast cancer, or undiagnosed vaginal bleeding . When prescribing HRT, it is crucial to consider the patient’s individual risk factors and tailor the therapy accordingly.
  • ➤ HRT
  • ➤ vasomotor symptoms
  • ➤ active liver disease, breast cancer, or undiagnosed vaginal bleeding

questions.text: An average woman is expected to experience how many ovulatory events during her reproductive lifetime?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 400

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An average woman experiences around 400 ovulatory events during her reproductive life. The number of available oocytes declines dramatically due to atresia, and menopause occurs when the remaining oocyte pool becomes depleted.
  • ➤ around 400 ovulatory events

questions.text: In the postmenopausal woman with uterine bleeding, evaluation of the endometrium may be accomplished by endometrial biopsy, hysteroscopy, or transvaginal sonography. Which of the following sonographic endometrial thickness measurements is commonly used as a threshold to indicate a low risk for endometrial hyperplasia or cancer?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 5mm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In postmenopausal women with abnormal uterine bleeding , an endometrial thickness ≤5 mm on TVS is reassuring and indicates a low likelihood of malignancy. An endometrial thickness >5 mm necessitates further investigation to exclude endometrial hyperplasia or endometrial cancer .
  • ➤ abnormal uterine bleeding
  • ➤ endometrial thickness ≤5 mm
  • ➤ >5 mm
  • ➤ endometrial hyperplasia
  • ➤ endometrial cancer

questions.text: What is the most common medical complaint of women during menopausal transition?

options.label: D
options.text: Vasomotor symptoms characterized as hot flashes

questions.correct_answer: D. Vasomotor symptoms characterized as hot flashes
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Vasomotor symptoms characterized as hot flashes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most common symptom experienced during the menopausal transition is vasomotor symptoms , including hot flashes and night sweats , due to declining estrogen levels. HRT remains the most effective treatment for moderate-to-severe vasomotor symptoms.
  • ➤ most common symptom
  • ➤ vasomotor symptoms
  • ➤ hot flashes
  • ➤ night sweats

questions.text: Which of the following infertility scenarios would warrant intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI)?

options.label: B
options.text: Infertility secondary to diminished ovarian reserve

options.label: C
options.text: Infertility secondary to bilateral distal fallopian tube occlusion

options.label: D
options.text: Infertility secondary to the male partner’s severe oligospermia

questions.correct_answer: D. Infertility secondary to the male partner’s severe oligospermia
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Infertility secondary to the male partner’s severe oligospermia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ ICSI is indicated in cases of severe male factor infertility , such as severe oligospermia , poor motility , or sperm retrieval procedures in cases of azoospermia . Conventional IVF is generally used for tubal factor infertility, while anovulation is treated with ovulation induction agents .
  • ➤ ICSI
  • ➤ severe male factor infertility
  • ➤ oligospermia
  • ➤ poor motility
  • ➤ sperm retrieval procedures
  • ➤ azoospermia
  • ➤ ovulation induction agents

questions.text: Egg donor recipients typically discontinue progesterone supplementation at which time?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 10 weeks’ gestation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In egg donor recipients and other IVF pregnancies, progesterone supplementation is required until 10–12 weeks' gestation , when the placenta takes over the production of progesterone to support the pregnancy.
  • ➤ egg donor recipients
  • ➤ progesterone supplementation
  • ➤ 10–12 weeks' gestation
  • ➤ placenta

questions.text: A 38-year-old with infertility secondary to tubal blockage just underwent in vitro fertilization (IVF). Her peak estradiol was 4500 pg/mL. Seventeen oocytes were retrieved, and two embryos were transferred. She conceived with a singleton gestation. She developed ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome. Which of the following was a predisposing factor in developing ovarian hyperstimulation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Estradiol level

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome (OHSS) is often triggered by high estradiol levels and multiple follicle recruitment during ovarian stimulation. Careful monitoring of estradiol levels and adjustment of gonadotropin doses during IVF can help prevent this complication. In high-risk cases, "freeze-all" cycles or triggering ovulation with a GnRH agonist instead of hCG can reduce the risk of OHSS.
  • ➤ Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome (OHSS)
  • ➤ high estradiol levels
  • ➤ multiple follicle recruitment
  • ➤ estradiol levels
  • ➤ adjustment of gonadotropin doses
  • ➤ "freeze-all" cycles
  • ➤ triggering ovulation with a GnRH agonist

questions.text: Septate uterus has a significantly higher spontaneous abortion rate and early pregnancy loss rate than bicornuate uterus. What is the primary mechanism thought to be responsible for this extraordinarily high pregnancy wastage?

options.label: C
options.text: Distortion of the uterine serosal contour

options.label: D
options.text: Partial or complete implantation on the largely avascular septum

questions.correct_answer: D. Partial or complete implantation on the largely avascular septum
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Partial or complete implantation on the largely avascular septum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The primary mechanism for pregnancy loss in a septate uterus is implantation on the avascular fibrous septum , which leads to insufficient blood supply for the growing gestation. Early diagnosis and surgical correction (hysteroscopic resection) can significantly improve reproductive outcomes.
  • ➤ septate uterus
  • ➤ implantation on the avascular fibrous septum

questions.text: Mullerian anomalies are associated with anomalies of all EXCEPT which of the following systems?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Liver

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Müllerian anomalies are commonly associated with renal, skeletal, and gastrointestinal anomalies , but they are not associated with liver anomalies .
  • ➤ renal, skeletal, and gastrointestinal anomalies
  • ➤ not associated with liver anomalies

questions.text: All EXCEPT which of the following characteristics of Klinefelter syndrome are true?

options.label: A
options.text: These patients are tall, over-virilized men

options.label: C
options.text: The syndrome occurs in 1 to 2 percent of all males

options.label: D
options.text: Men with Klinefelter syndrome are at increased risk for germ cell tumors, osteoporosis, and breast cancer.

questions.correct_answer: A. These patients are tall, over-virilized men
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) These patients are tall, over-virilized men

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Klinefelter syndrome, undervirilization is a hallmark feature, with tall stature, gynecomastia, and infertility being common. The primary endocrine abnormality is testicular failure , leading to low testosterone levels and subsequent estrogen dominance.
  • ➤ undervirilization
  • ➤ tall stature, gynecomastia, and infertility
  • ➤ testicular failure
  • ➤ low testosterone levels

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding sexual differentiation in humans?

options.label: A
options.text: The SRY acts as a testis-deleting factor (TDF)

options.label: B
options.text: Without the influence of SRY, gonads develop as testes

options.label: C
options.text: The gene is located on the Y chromosome and is named the sex-determining region of the Y (SRY)

options.label: D
options.text: The presence or absence of gonadal determinant genes is not thought to determine fetal gender

questions.correct_answer: C. The gene is located on the Y chromosome and is named the sex-determining region of the Y (SRY)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) The gene is located on the Y chromosome and is named the sex-determining region of the Y (SRY)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sexual differentiation is initiated by the presence of the SRY gene on the Y chromosome, which triggers testicular development. The absence of SRY leads to ovarian development. Key hormones like AMH , testosterone , and DHT play crucial roles in the development of internal and external male genitalia, while their absence allows for the development of female genitalia.
  • ➤ SRY gene
  • ➤ AMH
  • ➤ testosterone
  • ➤ DHT

questions.text: A 22-year-old obese nulligravida presents with a long history of irregular cycles and amenorrhea. After appropriate evaluation, you diagnose her with PCOS. Which of the following findings is LEAST likely to be seen in her condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Thickened, dark skin on the inner thighs

options.label: C
options.text: High serum levels of high-density lipoprotein

options.label: D
options.text: Male-pattern hair growth on the lower abdomen

questions.correct_answer: C. High serum levels of high-density lipoprotein
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) High serum levels of high-density lipoprotein

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Women with PCOS often have a dyslipidemia pattern of low HDL levels and high LDL and triglycerides , along with insulin resistance. High HDL levels are not typical in this condition and are the least likely finding . Managing PCOS includes lifestyle changes, insulin-sensitizing agents like metformin , and treatments to control hyperandrogenism and regulate menstrual cycles.
  • ➤ low HDL levels
  • ➤ high LDL and triglycerides
  • ➤ High HDL levels
  • ➤ least likely finding
  • ➤ metformin

questions.text: Which of the following hormones is the most effective in converting vellus hairs to terminal hairs?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Dihydrotestosterone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dihydrotestosterone (DHT) is the most potent androgen responsible for the conversion of vellus hairs to terminal hairs in androgen-dependent areas. Elevated DHT levels contribute to conditions such as hirsutism in women and androgenic alopecia in men.
  • ➤ Dihydrotestosterone (DHT)
  • ➤ vellus hairs to terminal hairs
  • ➤ hirsutism
  • ➤ androgenic alopecia

questions.text: In which of the following patients is a karyotype most likely needed?

options.label: B
options.text: 18-year-old with amenorrhea and an elevated prolactin level

options.label: C
options.text: 16-year-old with amenorrhea with normal secondary sexual characters and no mullerian structures on sonography

options.label: D
options.text: 16-year-old with amenorrhea with normal secondary sexual characters and uterus seen on imaging

questions.correct_answer: C. 16-year-old with amenorrhea with normal secondary sexual characters and no mullerian structures on sonography
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 16-year-old with amenorrhea with normal secondary sexual characters and no mullerian structures on sonography

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A karyotype is necessary to differentiate between Mullerian agenesis (MRKH) and Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (AIS) in a patient with primary amenorrhea, normal secondary sexual characteristics, and absence of Mullerian structures. These conditions have different genetic backgrounds (46,XX for MRKH and 46,XY for AIS), which guides appropriate management.
  • ➤ karyotype
  • ➤ Mullerian agenesis (MRKH)
  • ➤ Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (AIS)

questions.text: A 28-year-old nulligravida presents with primary amenorrhea. She is diagnosed with 46, XY gonadal dysgenesis. During pelvic laparoscopy, what is the expected finding?

options.label: A
options.text: Streak gonads and male internal genitalia

options.label: B
options.text: Streak gonads and female internal genitalia

options.label: C
options.text: Empty pelvis (no gonads or internal genitalia)

options.label: D
options.text: Bilateral abdominal testes and male internal genitalia

questions.correct_answer: B. Streak gonads and female internal genitalia
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Streak gonads and female internal genitalia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Swyer syndrome (46, XY gonadal dysgenesis) , the gonads fail to form functional testes, leading to streak gonads and female internal genitalia . The diagnosis necessitates gonadectomy to prevent malignancy.
  • ➤ Swyer syndrome (46, XY gonadal dysgenesis)
  • ➤ streak gonads
  • ➤ female internal genitalia
  • ➤ gonadectomy

questions.text: A 13-year-old female presents with increasing abdominal pain. She has begun appropriate pubertal development, although menarche has not occurred. During examination, a central abdominopelvic mass is appreciated. Physical examination findings prompt sonography and then magnetic resonance (MR) imaging with contrast. The MR imaging results are shown. Which of the following congenital anomalies is most likely present?

options.label: D
options.text: Obstructed hemivagina and ipsilateral renal anomaly (OHVIRA) syndrome

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Imperforate hymen

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Imperforate hymen is a common cause of primary amenorrhea and is associated with hematocolpos/hematometra due to outflow obstruction. Early recognition and prompt surgical correction (hymenotomy) can relieve symptoms and prevent complications.
  • ➤ Imperforate hymen
  • ➤ primary amenorrhea
  • ➤ hematocolpos/hematometra

questions.text: Which of the following statements is FALSE regarding development of the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis in the female fetus and neonate?

options.label: A
options.text: The gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) “pulse generator” remains functionally dormant until shortly after birth

options.label: B
options.text: By 5 months’ gestation, 6 to 7 million oocytes have been created from accelerated germ cell division

options.label: C
options.text: At birth, follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH) concentrations rise and remain high during the first 3 months of life

options.label: D
options.text: Neonatal breast budding, minor uterine bleeding, and transient ovarian cysts may occur as a normal response to initially high gonadotropin levels

questions.correct_answer: A. The gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) “pulse generator” remains functionally dormant until shortly after birth
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) The gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) “pulse generator” remains functionally dormant until shortly after birth

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The GnRH pulse generator in the HPO axis is dormant after infancy and becomes active only at puberty . Elevated FSH and LH levels in neonates are due to estrogen withdrawal, leading to transient but normal findings such as neonatal breast budding and vaginal bleeding .
  • ➤ GnRH pulse generator
  • ➤ puberty
  • ➤ FSH and LH levels
  • ➤ neonatal breast budding
  • ➤ vaginal bleeding

questions.text: The pathophysiology of primary dysmenorrhea is initiated by endometrial sloughing, during which endometrial cells release what substance that stimulates myometrial contractions and ischemia?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Prostaglandins

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Primary dysmenorrhea is caused by prostaglandin release from the endometrium, which stimulates myometrial contractions and uterine ischemia , resulting in menstrual pain. Treatment often involves NSAIDs , which inhibit prostaglandin synthesis.
  • ➤ prostaglandin release
  • ➤ myometrial contractions
  • ➤ uterine ischemia
  • ➤ NSAIDs

questions.text: During the physical examination for chronic pelvic pain, the technique shown here should be included. Nodularity may be found most commonly with which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Endometriosis or neoplasia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nodularity in the pouch of Douglas during a pelvic examination is highly suggestive of rectovaginal endometriosis or malignancy . In contrast, tenderness is more characteristic of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) . Evaluation of pelvic masses and nodules often requires follow-up with imaging and sometimes laparoscopy for confirmation.
  • ➤ pouch of Douglas
  • ➤ rectovaginal endometriosis
  • ➤ malignancy
  • ➤ tenderness
  • ➤ pelvic inflammatory disease (PID)

questions.text: Women seeking immediate fertility and who suffer from endometriosis would most likely benefit from which of the following treatments?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Laparoscopic ablation of lesions

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For women with endometriosis-associated infertility , laparoscopic ablation or excision of lesions is the optimal treatment to improve fertility outcomes. Medical therapy is mainly reserved for managing pain and delaying progression of endometriosis but does not promote conception.
  • ➤ endometriosis-associated infertility
  • ➤ laparoscopic ablation or excision of lesions

questions.text: A 20-year-old nulligravida with a last menstrual period 5 days ago presents to the emergency department with generalized lower abdominal pain and fever. She reports a new sexual partner. Physical examination demonstrates guarding and bilateral adnexal fullness. Laboratory studies show leukocytosis, and transvaginal sonography reveals no visible ovaries, but bilateral adnexal masses as shown here. The diagnosis most consistent with these findings is which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Tuboovarian abscess

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A tubo-ovarian abscess (TOA) is a late complication of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) and presents with fever, pelvic pain, adnexal masses, and leukocytosis . Prompt recognition is crucial, as untreated TOA can lead to rupture and sepsis, necessitating aggressive antibiotic therapy and sometimes surgical intervention.
  • ➤ tubo-ovarian abscess (TOA)
  • ➤ pelvic inflammatory disease (PID)
  • ➤ fever, pelvic pain, adnexal masses, and leukocytosis

questions.text: A 30-year-old parous woman visits the nearest STD center as she is having lesions at the vulva. After examination, she is prescribed a red coloured kit. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Genital herpes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The red-colored kit in syndromic STI management is used for the treatment of herpetic genital ulcers .
  • ➤ red-colored kit
  • ➤ herpetic genital ulcers

questions.text: A patient for whom you initiated combination oral contraceptive pills (COCs) 3 months ago returns to the OPD for a routine COC reevaluation. She complains of light but irregular bleeding during this time, but states that it is improving. What is your diagnosis and plan of care?

options.label: B
options.text: Breakthrough bleeding requiring counseling and reassurance

options.label: D
options.text: Hormonal imbalance requiring selection of a different COC formula

questions.correct_answer: B. Breakthrough bleeding requiring counseling and reassurance
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Breakthrough bleeding requiring counseling and reassurance

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Breakthrough bleeding is a common side effect during the initial months of low-dose combination oral contraceptive use and usually resolves with time. Counseling and reassurance are key to patient management.

questions.text: The most common etiologies of bleeding have been correctly paired with their age demographic in all EXCEPT which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Menopause—endometrial carcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most common cause of postmenopausal bleeding is endometrial atrophy , not malignancy, though malignancy must be ruled out through detailed evaluation.
  • ➤ endometrial atrophy

questions.text: For carefully selected patients, medical management of ectopic pregnancy using methotrexate is associated with what overall resolution rate?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 90 percent

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The overall resolution rate of medical management of ectopic pregnancy using methotrexate in carefully selected patients is approximately 90% . The efficacy of methotrexate depends on appropriate patient selection and consistent monitoring of β-hCG levels.
  • ➤ 90%

questions.text: A 19-year-old female college student is diagnosed with a pelvic mass and an elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) level. She reports that she was amenorrheic until she started taking combination oral contraceptive pills (COCs). She undergoes surgical exploration, and frozen section analysis of the surgical specimen reveals ovarian dysgerminoma. Which of the following is FALSE?

options.label: B
options.text: Regardless of stage, she has an excellent prognosis

options.label: C
options.text: Her other ovary may contain a gonadoblastoma and should be removed

options.label: D
options.text: She should undergo complete surgical staging, but her uterus may be preserved.

questions.correct_answer: A. Her karyotype is most likely 46XX
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Her karyotype is most likely 46XX

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dysgerminomas are highly associated with gonadal dysgenesis and typically occur in patients with a 46XY karyotype (e.g., Swyer syndrome). These tumors have an excellent prognosis, and management often involves fertility-preserving surgery, with removal of dysgenetic gonads due to the risk of malignancy.
  • ➤ 46XY karyotype

questions.text: Of the hysterectomy types, which has the highest risk of bladder and ureteral injury?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Laparoscopic hysterectomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Laparoscopic hysterectomy has the highest risk of bladder and ureteral injury due to the use of electrocautery and limited tactile sensation. In contrast, vaginal hysterectomy has the lowest risk of injury to adjacent pelvic organs.
  • ➤ highest risk of bladder and ureteral injury

questions.text: All EXCEPT which of the following procedures are commonly performed concomitantly with Lefort partial Colpocleisis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Vaginal hysterectomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ LeFort partial colpocleisis is a uterine-preserving surgery for pelvic organ prolapse and is often combined with procedures such as cystoscopy, perineorrhaphy, and anti-incontinence procedures. Vaginal hysterectomy is not performed as part of this approach.
  • ➤ not

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman is referred to the gyn OPD with an incidental finding of b/l solid ovarian masses on an ultrasound. She is a known case of breast cancer treated a few years back. A biopsy of the masses shows the following image. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Krukenberg tumor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A Krukenberg tumor is a metastatic ovarian tumor that most commonly arises from the stomach and is histologically characterized by signet ring cells . It is often bilateral and may also arise from breast cancer metastases.
  • ➤ signet ring cells

questions.text: What is the most common method of ovarian cancer spread?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Tumor exfoliation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most common method of ovarian cancer spread is tumor exfoliation , where cancer cells shed from the primary tumor and disseminate throughout the peritoneal cavity, leading to peritoneal and omental metastases.
  • ➤ tumor exfoliation

questions.text: A patient came to the gynecology OPD with complaints of foul-smelling frothy vaginal discharge and intense itching. On examination, the cervix was spotted and had the appearance of a strawberry. Identify the causative organism.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Trichomonas vaginalis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Trichomonas vaginalis infection is characterized by foul-smelling frothy vaginal discharge , intense itching , and the presence of a strawberry cervix . It is an STI, and diagnosis involves identifying motile trichomonads on a wet mount.
  • ➤ Trichomonas vaginalis
  • ➤ foul-smelling frothy vaginal discharge
  • ➤ intense itching
  • ➤ strawberry cervix
